questions.text: Which of the following represents a holocrine gland? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B

 

The histopathological image marked 'B' represents the sebaceous gland, which is a type of holocrine gland.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Options A: Image A. Sweat glands - Eccrine/merocrine glands; glands remain intact

 

 

Options C: Image C. Mammary gland - Apocrine gland; apical part sheds to secrete

 

 

Option D: Image D. Ceruminous gland - Apocrine glands

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Holocrine secretions are produced in the cytoplasm of the cell and released by the rupture of the plasma membrane, which destroys the cell and results in the secretion of the product into the lumen.

 

Examples of holocrine glands are: -

 

  • Sebaceous glands of the skin and
  • Meibomian glands of the eyelid

questions.text: A student got his jaw locked while yawning. Identify the muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Lateral pterygoid

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle attached to the articular disc of the temporomandibular joint is the lateral pterygoid.

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle has two heads: superior (or upper) and inferior (or lower). The superior head attaches to the articular disc and the capsule of the temporomandibular joint (TMJ). This muscle plays a crucial role in the opening of the mouth, protrusion of the mandible, and moving the jaw from side to side. Dysfunction or spasms of this muscle could contribute to jaw locking during yawning. The lateral pterygoid is, therefore, closely associated with the movements and function of the TMJ.

 

All Innervated by CN V3

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Temporalis: The temporalis muscle originates from the temporal fossa and inserts onto the coronoid process of the mandible. It's primarily responsible for closing the mouth and is involved in elevating and retracting the mandible. It does not attach to the articular disc of the TMJ, but it plays a role in jaw movement.

 

Option C. Medial pterygoid: The medial pterygoid muscle is similar in function to the masseter muscle and helps in elevating the mandible, thus assisting in closing the mouth. It also plays a role in moving the jaw from side to side. However, like the temporalis, it doesn't directly attach to the articular disc of the TMJ.

 

Option D. Masseter: The masseter muscle is one of the primary muscles of mastication (chewing). It originates from the zygomatic arch and inserts onto the lateral aspect of the mandibular angle and ramus. Its primary function is to elevate the mandible, assisting in closing the mouth. It does not have an attachment to the articular disc of the TMJ but is important for jaw function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral pterygoid muscle, particularly its superior head, is uniquely attached to the TMJ's articular disc and plays a pivotal role in jaw movements including mouth opening and lateral movements, making it relevant in cases of jaw locking.

questions.text: Which joint is not formed by the bone shown in the image? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Synchondrosis

 

The image shows a thoracic vertebra, identifiable by its long spinous process, body, and superior and inferior articular facets. Thoracic vertebrae participate in forming several types of joints but do not form synchondroses. A synchondrosis is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are joined by hyaline cartilage, which is not present in the thoracic vertebra.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syndesmosis: Incorrect. Syndesmosis joints are formed where two bones are connected by a ligament. An example related to the vertebrae would be the interspinous ligament connecting adjacent spinous processes.

 

Option C. Plane joint: Incorrect. Plane joints are formed by thoracic vertebrae, such as the costovertebral and costotransverse joints, where the ribs articulate with the thoracic vertebrae.

 

Option D. Symphysis: Incorrect. Symphysis joints are formed between the vertebral bodies of adjacent thoracic vertebrae via the intervertebral discs, which are composed of fibrocartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracic vertebrae do not form synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous) joints; they are involved in forming plane joints, syndesmosis, and symphysis joints.

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve pass through? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation

 

The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve passes through the foramen ovale which is marked as 4 in the above image.

 

The foramen ovale is also located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

 

The structure that passes through the foramen ovale is the mandibular nerve (the third division of the trigeminal nerve, Cranial Nerve V3). It carries sensory information from the face and provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Foramen ovale is situated anterior and medial to foramen spinosum, and is larger in size than spinosum.


Structures passing vis foramen ovale can be remembered by the following mnemonic
M - Mandibular nerve (3rd division of trigeminal)
A - Accessory meningeal artery
L - Lesser petrosal nerve
E - emissary veins
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • The foramen spinosum is a small foramen located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, near the foramen ovale.
  • The structure that passes through the foramen spinosum is the middle meningeal artery. This artery supplies blood to the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

 

Option B. Internal Acoustic Meatus:

 

  • The internal acoustic meatus is located in the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • Several important structures pass through this foramen:
    1. Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII): It carries motor and sensory fibers related to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    2. Vestibulocochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII): It carries sensory information related to hearing and balance.

 

Option C. Jugular Foramen:

 

  • The jugular foramen is located at the junction of the temporal and occipital bones, near the base of the skull.
  • Several structures pass through the jugular foramen:
    1. Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX): It carries motor and sensory fibers to the pharynx and taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    2. Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X): It carries motor and sensory fibers to various organs in the thorax and abdomen and plays a crucial role in autonomic functions.
    3. Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI): It supplies motor fibers to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
    4. Internal jugular vein: It is a major vein that drains blood from the brain and parts of the face.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient underwent surgery for the varicose vein. He now complains of sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Saphenous nerve

 

The given clinical scenario in a patient with sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot is suggestive of injury to the saphenous nerve. Injury to the saphenous nerve is common following varicose vein surgery.

 

Saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve.

 

Sensory Distribution: The saphenous nerve is the longest cutaneous nerve in the body and provides sensation to the anteromedial aspect of the leg down to the medial side of the foot.

 

Clinical Relevance: Injury to the saphenous nerve, particularly during varicose vein surgery given its proximity to the great saphenous vein, would result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sural nerve:  It is formed by the joining of branches from the tibial nerve and the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It supplies sensation to the lateral and posterior aspect of the lower leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the sural nerve would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Superficial peroneal nerve:  Branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: It provides sensation to the anterolateral aspect of the leg and the dorsum (top) of the foot, excluding the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage to this nerve would cause sensory loss on the dorsum of the foot and the anterolateral aspect of the leg but not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option C. Deep peroneal nerve: Another branch of the common peroneal nerve.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Its sensory distribution is limited and includes the web space between the first and second toes.
  • Clinical Relevance: Injury to the deep peroneal nerve would affect the sensation between the first and second toes and would not result in sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

 

Explanation:

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome, is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option C. Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery: The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.

 

Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.

 

Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation:

 

Presynaptic secretory vesicles are indicated by the asterisk in the electron micrograph. The structure with the arrowhead represents postsynaptic density.

 

Neurons produce secretory vesicles, which are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.

 

Synapse - electron microscopy

 

 

On electron microscopy:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondria- On an electron microscope, mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies 0.5-2.0 micron long, with an outer and inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B.  Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory vesicles are essential for neurotransmission at synapses, and play the critical role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a 33-hour chick embryo. Which of the following is derived from the marked structure? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ribs

 

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image is the para-axial mesoderm. In the 33-hour chick embryo, the para-axial mesoderm is situated on each side of the neural tube and notochord. This mesoderm divides into segments known as somites. Somites further differentiate into sclerotome, myotome, and dermatome.
  • The sclerotome, derived from the somites, gives rise to the vertebrae and ribs. The para-axial mesoderm is responsible for forming these segmented structures, essential components of the axial skeleton.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kidney: Incorrect. The kidney is derived from the intermediate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option B. Dorsal root ganglion: Incorrect. The dorsal root ganglion is derived from neural crest cells, which are separate from the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Option C. Parietal pleura: Incorrect. The parietal pleura is derived from the lateral plate mesoderm, not the para-axial mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The para-axial mesoderm forms somites, which give rise to the vertebrae and ribs.

choices.text: Common bile duct

questions.text: Which body part contains the type of epithelium shown in the image? (AIIMS NOV  2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Urinary bladder

 

Explanation:

 

The urinary bladder is lined by a specialized epithelium known as transitional epithelium or urothelium. This epithelium is uniquely suited for the urinary bladder and parts of the urinary tract due to its ability to stretch significantly without losing its cellular integrity. Transitional epithelium appears as a multilayered system that can transition from a thicker, relaxed state to a thinner, stretched state as the bladder fills and empties. This dynamic ability is crucial for accommodating varying volumes of urine.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option a (Bile duct) and option b (Common bile duct) are incorrect because the bile ducts are primarily lined by simple cuboidal or simple columnar epithelium, not transitional epithelium.
  • Option c (Skin) is also incorrect as the skin is covered by stratified squamous epithelium, which is protective in function and markedly different in structure and function from the transitional epithelium found in the urinary bladder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The urinary bladder is lined by transitional epithelium, also known as urothelium, which allows it to stretch and contract as needed. This type of epithelium is essential for the proper functioning of the bladder.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the area marked A in the given image is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dopamine

 

Explanation:

 

The substantia nigra is the region highlighted in the illustration (meaning- dark substance). Dopamine is the neurotransmitter released by this region.

 

A component of the nigrostriatal pathway is the substantia nigra. Parkinson's disease may be caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine (ACh):

 

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS).
  • In the PNS, ACh is the neurotransmitter released from the axon terminals of motor neurons, making muscles contract. It's also the neurotransmitter in all autonomic ganglia.
  • In the CNS, ACh is involved in a variety of functions, such as attention, arousal, and memory. Loss of cholinergic neurons in the brain, especially in the basal nucleus of Meynert, has been linked with Alzheimer's disease.
  • However, ACh is not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Glutamine:

 

  • It's worth noting that there's a potential mix-up in the options: Glutamine is an amino acid, while "glutamate" is the neurotransmitter.
  • Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS and plays crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, which is the cellular basis for learning and memory.
  • While glutamate is widespread in the brain, it's not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Noradrenaline :

 

  • Noradrenaline is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter. It plays roles in attention, focus, and the fight-or-flight response by preparing the body to react to threats.
  • In the CNS, noradrenergic neurons primarily arise from the locus coeruleus in the pons and project to various regions of the brain, influencing attention, arousal, and mood.
  • While noradrenaline plays a role in various brain functions, it's not the neurotransmitter secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine:

 

Dopamine is one of the major neurotransmitters in the brain and is involved in several key functions, including mood regulation, reward-seeking behavior, and motor control.

 

The substantia nigra, specifically its pars compacta region, contains dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). This pathway is known as the nigrostriatal pathway and is critical for regulating voluntary movement.

 

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is the primary pathological feature of Parkinson's disease, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.

choices.text: Its diameter is less than left coronary artery
It arises from the anterior aortic sinus
It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch
Right conus artery is its first branch

questions.text: All of the following are true about the right coronary artery except?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It gives rise to circumflex coronary branch

 

  • This statement is false. The circumflex coronary artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. The circumflex artery travels in the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle and supplies the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.
  • Originating from the right coronary sinus of the ascending aorta, the right coronary artery has a smaller diameter compared to the left coronary artery.
  • It courses anteriorly and descends perpendicularly along the coronary sulcus, situated between the right atrium and the right ventricle.
  • Upon reaching the inferior border, it takes a posterior turn and persists along the sulcus onto the diaphragmatic surface and base of the heart.

 

 

Branches of right coronary artery:

 

  • Atrial branches are anterior, posterior and lateral. One of the anterior atrial branches is called SA nodal artery.
  • Right conus artery – it is usually the first branch. It forms an arterial circle around pulmonary trunk with a similar branch from the left coronary artery. The circle is called, ‘annulus of Vieussen’s’.
  • Ventricular branches are as anterior and posterior groups.
  • Right marginal artery
  • Posterior interventricular branch

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Its diameter is less than left coronary artery: This is true. The right coronary artery (RCA) typically has a smaller diameter compared to the left main coronary artery. The left coronary artery further divides into the left anterior descending (LAD) and the circumflex arteries, which are primary arteries supplying a significant portion of the heart, especially in left-dominant circulatory systems.

 

Option B. It arises from the anterior aortic sinus: This is true. The RCA arises from the anterior aortic sinus (also known as the right coronary sinus) of the aorta. It's one of the three aortic sinuses located just above the aortic valve. The other two sinuses give rise to the left coronary artery and have no coronary artery associated with them, respectively.

 

Option D. Right conal (or conus) artery is its first branch: This is true. The first branch of the RCA, in many individuals, is the conal or conus artery, which supplies the conus arteriosus of the right ventricle. After this, the RCA travels in the coronary sulcus and gives off other branches like the right marginal artery and, in many people, the posterior descending artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The circumflex coronary artery is actually a branch of the left coronary artery, not the right. It travels along the coronary sulcus between the left atrium and left ventricle, primarily supplying the left atrium and the posterior walls of the left ventricle.

questions.text:
Which of the following cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum?(INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Stellate cells

2. Basket cells

3. Purkinje cells

4. Granular cells
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum contains stellate and basket cells.

 

The molecular layer is one of the three layers of the cerebellar cortex, along with the granular layer and the Purkinje cell layer. It is involved in the processing of sensory information, as well as motor planning and coordination. The stellate and basket cells within the molecular layer provide inhibitory feedback to the Purkinje cells, which are the only output neurons of the cerebellar cortex.

 

The parallel fibres, which originate from granule cells in the granular layer, run perpendicular to the Purkinje cell dendrites and provide excitatory input to the molecular layer. As the parallel fibres traverse the molecular layer, they make multiple synapses with the dendrites of Purkinje cells, where inhibitory synapses are formed. This allows the Purkinje cells to integrate the incoming excitatory and inhibitory signals and adjust their output accordingly.

 

Overall, the molecular layer plays a crucial role in the cerebellar circuitry and contributes to the precision of motor movements and balance.

 

 

1. Stellate cells:

  • Location: Stellate cells are present in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are inhibitory interneurons that primarily release GABA (gamma-aminobutyric acid) and inhibit the dendrites of Purkinje cells.
     

2. Basket cells:

  • Location: Basket cells are also located in the molecular layer of the cerebellum.
  • Function: These are another type of inhibitory interneuron. The axons of basket cells form "baskets" around the cell bodies of Purkinje cells, releasing GABA and inhibiting them.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Purkinje cells:

  • Location: Purkinje cells form their own distinct layer known as the Purkinje cell layer, which is situated between the molecular layer and the granular layer.
  • Function: These cells are the primary output neurons of the cerebellar cortex. They have large, flattened dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer, receiving inputs from climbing fibers and parallel fibers. The axons of Purkinje cells send inhibitory projections to the cerebellar nuclei.
     

4. Granular cells:

  • Location: Granular cells are present in the granular layer, which is the innermost layer of the cerebellar cortex.
  • Function: These cells receive inputs from mossy fibers, which originate from various brainstem nuclei and the spinal cord. Granular cells send their axons into the molecular layer, where they bifurcate to form parallel fibers. These parallel fibers synapse onto the dendrites of Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular layer of the cerebellum primarily contains stellate and basket cells. This layer is one of three distinct layers of the cerebellar cortex and is crucial for integrating sensory and motor information to refine motor coordination and balance.

questions.text: Which of the following veins drain into brachiocephalic vein? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Left superior intercostal vein

 

Explanation:

 

The left superior intercostal vein  directly drain into the brachiocephalic vein. This vein collects venous blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemiazygous Vein: The hemiazygous vein is a tributary of the azygos vein, not the brachiocephalic vein. It drains blood from the left side of the posterior thoracic wall.

 

Option B. Superior Thyroid Vein : It drain into the internal jugular vein, not directly into the brachiocephalic vein. They carry blood from the thyroid gland.

 

Option C. Right Superior Intercostal Vein: It is formed by union of 2nd, 3rd, and 4th right posterior intercostal veins). It drains into the azygous vein. It serves as a major channel for venous blood from the right side of the posterior thoracic wall to return to the superior vena cava and ultimately to the right atrium of the heart.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tributaries of the brachiocephalic vein:

 

  • Left and right internal thoracic veins
  • Left and right inferior thyroid veins
  • Left superior intercostal vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein.
  • The right superior intercostal vein drains into the azygos vein.

questions.text: What is the volume of the prostate in normal adult males? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20cc

 

Explanation:

 

The volume of the prostate in normal adult males is 20cc.

 

The volume of the prostate gland in normal adult males can vary depending on age and other factors. However, on average, the volume of the prostate gland in an adult male is around 20-30 cubic centimeters (cc) or milliliters (mL).

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical volume of the prostate in a normal adult male is around 20cc

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

choices.text: Cranial nerves III, V, VII, X and sacral nerves S1, S2, S3, S4, S5
Cranial nerves III, VII, IX, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4
Cranial nerves V, VII, IX, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4
Cranial nerves III, V, VII, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4

questions.text: Which components form part of the parasympathetic nervous system? (AIIMS NOV  2016)
questions.solution:
Answer: B. Cranial nerves III, VII, IX, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4.

 

Explanation:

 

The parasympathetic nervous system, often described as the craniosacral division of the autonomic nervous system (ANS), includes specific cranial and sacral nerves. The nerves involved are the oculomotor nerve (III), the facial nerve (VII), the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), and the vagus nerve (X) from the cranial component. From the sacral part, the second to fourth sacral nerves (S2, S3, S4) are included. These nerves contribute to the parasympathetic functions of the body, which include reducing the heart rate, increasing glandular secretion, and relaxing sphincters among other roles. The neurons of these nerves are primarily responsible for transmitting rest and digest signals to various organs, providing a balance against the sympathetic nervous system's fight or flight responses.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A (Cranial nerves III, V, VII, X and sacral nerves S1, S2, S3, S4, S5) is incorrect because it incorrectly includes cranial nerve V and sacral nerves S1 and S5, which are not part of the parasympathetic system.
  • Option C (Cranial nerves V, VII, IX, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4) is incorrect as it wrongly includes cranial nerve V.
  • Option D (Cranial nerves III, V, VII, X and sacral nerves S2, S3, S4) also includes cranial nerve V mistakenly and therefore is not accurate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

parasympathetic nervous system is composed of cranial nerves III, VII, IX, and X, along with sacral nerves S2, S3, and S4. This system plays a key role in the body's rest and digest functions, contrasting the sympathetic system's fight or flight responses

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abduction

 

Explanation:

 

The greater trochanter is visible in the photograph, and the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscle fibres attach (insert) here. Action of these fibres of abducting the leg, and their anterior fibres rotate the thigh medially.

 

Both are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

 

Hip abduction involves moving the thigh laterally, away from the midline. This is the primary function of both the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. When you stand on one leg, these muscles contract on the standing side to prevent the pelvis from tilting down on the free side. This stabilizing action is crucial for bipedal walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion: Hip flexion primarily involves lifting the thigh forward in an anterior direction. While the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus can assist in flexion when the hip is initially in extension, this is not their primary function. Main hip flexors include the iliopsoas, rectus femoris, and sartorius.

 

Option B. Adduction: Hip adduction is the action of moving the thigh medially, towards the midline. Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus are not adductors; in fact, they act in opposition to this movement. The primary hip adductors include muscles like the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, gracilis, and pectineus.

 

Option D. Extension: Hip extension involves moving the thigh posteriorly. The primary hip extensor is the gluteus maximus, which is the largest of the gluteal muscles. While the gluteus medius and minimus can assist in hip extension when the hip is initially flexed, this is not their main action.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Explanation:

 

The occipitotemporal fracture in the clinical scenario is suggestive of involvement of the 9th and 10th cranial nerves, which are tested by pressing on the uvula, which is indicated as 2 in the image.

 

The jugular foramen is located between the lower border of the petrous part of the temporal bone and the condylar part of the occipital bone. As the investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region, along with the history of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, are suggestive of injury to the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve passing through the jugular foramen.

 

Unilateral lesions of IX and X cranial nerves are commonly caused by skull-base fractures, strokes, or tumors.

 

Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve examination include:

 

  • Observing the position and symmetry of the palate and uvula(marked as 2 in the given image) at rest and with phonation ("aah").
  • The pharyngeal (gag") reflex is evaluated by stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall on each side with a sterile, blunt object (e.g., tongue blade)

 

Individuals who have a proximal unilateral vagus nerve lesion report having trouble swallowing. On the affected side, the soft palate muscles will be weak. When the patient is asked to utter "aah," for example, an attempt to elevate the soft palate voluntarily will demonstrate a deficit in that side's ability to do so. Due to the palatal muscles' unopposed action on that side, there will also be a deviation of the uvula to the typical side along with this.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. 1: This area does not relate to the glossopharyngeal or vagus nerves, which are crucial in the described symptoms.

 

Option. C. 3: This area is likely distant from the jugular foramen where nerves IX and X pass, thus not directly involved with the symptoms presented.

 

Option. D. 4: This lower section of the brain and skull does not typically involve the pathways or exit points of the cranial nerves implicated in swallowing and speech functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of occipitotemporal fractures with symptoms of difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech, it is critical to assess the function of the glossopharyngeal and vagus nerves, as these are commonly affected by such injuries. Testing should focus on the functionality of the palate and uvula where these nerves can be clinically evaluated.

questions.text: Which of the following structures given below is related to the structure highlighted green in image? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pudendal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in green is the ischial spine and the pudendal nerve is related to it.

 

The ischial spine is a bony projection from the posterior part of the ischium in the pelvis

 

The pudendal nerve originates from the sacral plexus S2-S4. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor by passing around the ischial spine. The ischial spine is used as a landmark for pudendal nerve block.

 

 

  1. Sensory function: The pudendal nerve provides sensation to the external genitalia, perineum, and anus.
  2. Motor function: The pudendal nerve also supplies motor function to the pelvic floor muscles, including the external anal sphincter, bulbospongiosus muscle, and ischiocavernosus muscle.
  3. Sexual function: The pudendal nerve plays a crucial role in sexual function by supplying motor and sensory innervation to the genital organs.
  4. Urinary and fecal continence: The pudendal nerve is involved in maintaining urinary and fecal continence by controlling the external anal sphincter muscle. Damage to the pudendal nerve can lead to incontinence, which is the loss of control over urinary or fecal elimination.Top of Form

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve is the largest nerve in the body and originates from the sacral plexus (L4-S3). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, below the piriformis muscle. While it is near the ischial spine, it descends posteriorly down the thigh, dividing into the tibial and common fibular (peroneal) nerves. It provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior thigh and most of the leg and foot. Its relation to the ischial spine is less clinically significant than the pudendal nerve's.

 

Option C. Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen and provides sensory and motor innervation to the medial thigh. In terms of its relationship to the ischial spine, it is anatomically distinct, as it courses more anteriorly in the pelvis, and it doesn't have significant clinical associations with the ischial spine.

 

Option D. Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve also originates from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4). It descends through the psoas muscle and enters the thigh beneath the inguinal ligament. It provides motor innervation to the anterior thigh muscles and sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. The femoral nerve's course is anterior in the pelvis, and it doesn't have a direct relationship or significant clinical association with the ischial spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pudendal nerve arises from the sacral plexus (S2-S4 nerve roots). It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, just inferior to the piriformis muscle. It then courses around the ischial spine and re-enters the pelvis through the lesser sciatic foramen. The pudendal nerve provides sensory and motor innervation to the perineal region and external genitalia. Due to its proximity to the ischial spine, the pudendal nerve can be blocked for pain relief during childbirth and certain surgical procedures in the perineal region.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Foramen rotundum

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows the sphenoid bone. The foramen marked is the foramen rotundum. Maxillary branch of trigeminal nerve passes through it.

 

 

The foramen rotundum is a small circular opening in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull. It serves as a passage for the maxillary nerve (CN V2), which is one of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve.

 

The maxillary nerve exits the cranial cavity through the foramen rotundum and then travels through the pterygopalatine fossa, where it gives off several branches that innervate the maxillary teeth, the maxillary sinus, and the skin of the face in the maxillary region.

 

Other structures that may pass through the foramen rotundum include small blood vessels and veins, but these are less significant than the maxillary nerve in terms of clinical relevance.

 

Other Options :

 

Option B. Foramen Ovale:

 

  • Location: The foramen ovale is also located in the sphenoid bone, adjacent (Postero- lateral) to the foramen rotundum.
  • Contents: It transmits the mandibular nerve (another branch of the trigeminal nerve or CN V3), the accessory meningeal artery, and sometimes a small emissary vein.

 

Option C. Vidian Canal (Pterygoid Canal):

 

  • Location: The vidian canal is a small canal in the sphenoid bone, extending from the pterygopalatine fossa to the middle cranial fossa.
  • Contents: It contains the vidian nerve, which is a branch of the maxillary nerve (CN V2), as well as the vidian artery and sympathetic fibers.

 

Option D. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • Location: The foramen spinosum is situated in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. It is present postero-lateral to foramen ovale
  • Contents: It transmits the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, and the middle meningeal vein.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus
Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis

questions.text: Which of the following forms the lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus

 

The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the lateral aspect of the wrist and the base of the thumb. When the thumb is extended, this depression becomes more pronounced. The lateral boundary of the anatomical snuff box is formed by extensor pollicis brevis and abductor pollicis longus. When you extend and abduct the thumb, you can typically feel these tendons, especially the abductor pollicis longus, become taut along the lateral border of the wrist, outlining the snuffbox.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. It extends the thumb's distal phalanx. The abductor pollicis brevis is a muscle of the thenar eminence and doesn't directly contribute to the boundaries of the anatomical snuffbox. Its tendon is not found in this region; instead, it inserts into the base of the thumb's proximal phalanx.

 

Option C. Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis: As already mentioned, the extensor pollicis longus forms the medial boundary of the anatomical snuffbox. The extensor pollicis brevis, in conjunction with the abductor pollicis longus, forms the lateral boundary. However, they don't together form just one boundary of the snuffbox.

 

Option D. Abductor pollicis longus and abductor pollicis brevis: The abductor pollicis longus contributes to the lateral boundary of the snuffbox, as mentioned above. The abductor pollicis brevis, on the other hand, doesn't form any part of the snuffbox boundaries.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Striate cortex (Primary visual cortex)

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient presents with visual disturbances, particularly difficulty integrating visual information from both eyes. Imaging studies reveal a lesion affecting a specific area of the brain associated with the transfer of visual information between the cerebral hemispheres. The neurologist points to the structure labelled 'A' in the brain MRI, emphasizing its role in visual processing. Which of the following structures is connected to the one labelled as 'A' in the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Striate cortex (Primary visual cortex)

 

Explanation:

 

The structure labelled 'A' in the image is the splenium of the corpus callosum, which primarily connects the occipital lobes and facilitates communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres. The splenium plays a crucial role in transferring visual information between the hemispheres, allowing the integration of visual inputs from both eyes. This connection involves the striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex (V1), which processes basic visual features such as edges, motion, and orientation. The splenium's fibers enable bilateral visual integration, crucial for creating a cohesive visual perception.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory formation and spatial navigation, located inferiorly to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It does not have direct connections with the splenium for visual processing, as its primary role is unrelated to interhemispheric communication of visual data.

 

C. Thalamus: The thalamus is a relay center for sensory and motor signals, particularly involved in processing sensory information before it reaches the cerebral cortex. Although it plays a crucial role in visual pathways, it does not directly connect to the splenium of the corpus callosum.

 

D. Basal ganglia: The basal ganglia are associated with motor control, movement regulation, and various cognitive functions but do not directly connect with the splenium. They are not involved in interhemispheric visual data transfer or processing, making this an incorrect choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The splenium of the corpus callosum connects the occipital lobes and the striate cortex (primary visual cortex), facilitating communication between the left and right hemispheres for the integration of visual information. This connection is essential for cohesive visual perception and bilateral processing of visual stimuli.

questions.text: The sulcus located deep to the marked structure is? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stem of the lateral sulcus

 

 

  • The marked structure in the image points to the region where the parietal lobe and temporal lobe meet. This region is associated with the lateral sulcus, also known as the Sylvian fissure. The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to this marked structure, separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central sulcus: Incorrect. The central sulcus separates the frontal lobe from the parietal lobe and is not located in the region marked in the image.

 

Option C. Inferior frontal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus is found on the lateral surface of the frontal lobe and does not correspond to the marked region.

 

Option D. Superior temporal sulcus: Incorrect. This sulcus runs parallel to the lateral sulcus on the temporal lobe, but it is not deep to the marked structure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stem of the lateral sulcus is located deep to the marked structure in the image, which is a critical landmark in neuroanatomy for separating the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.

questions.text: Which ligament connects medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lisfranc

 

Explanation:

 

The Lisfranc ligament connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal.

 

The ligament that connects the medial cuneiform to the base of the 2nd metatarsal is called the "Lisfranc ligament".

 

The Lisfranc ligament is a strong band of fibrous tissue that connects the medial cuneiform bone to the base of the second metatarsal bone in the foot. It is named after Jacques Lisfranc, a French surgeon who described amputations through this region during the Napoleonic Wars. The Lisfranc joint complex also includes the articulation between the other cuneiform bones and the metatarsals, as well as the tarsometatarsal ligaments and interosseous ligaments. The Lisfranc ligament is important for maintaining stability of the midfoot and for transferring forces from the hindfoot to the forefoot during walking and running. Injuries to the Lisfranc joint can result in significant disability and may require surgery to repair or stabilize the joint.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chopart Ligament: Chopart's ligament is not a well-known ligament in the foot. The term "Chopart joint" typically refers to the midtarsal joint, which includes the articulation between the talus and navicular (talocalcaneonavicular joint) and the calcaneus and cuboid (calcaneocuboid joint). Ligaments associated with these joints help maintain their stability.

 

Option B. Spring Ligament: The spring ligament, also known as the plantar calcaneonavicular ligament, connects the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus to the navicular bone. It is a vital structure for supporting the arch of the foot and preventing its collapse.

 

Option D. Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is located on the medial side of the ankle joint. It is a complex ligament that attaches to the medial malleolus of the tibia and connects to various tarsal bones, such as the talus, calcaneus, and navicular. The deltoid ligament plays a significant role in stabilizing the ankle joint and preventing excessive eversion (outward rolling) of the foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lisfranc ligament is specifically associated with the connection between the medial cuneiform and the base of the 2nd metatarsal. It is a strong ligament that helps stabilize the midfoot and prevents dislocation of the tarsometatarsal (TMT) joints. Injury to this ligament is commonly referred to as a Lisfranc injury, which can result from traumatic events like falls or sports injuries.

choices.text: Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.

 

CREUTZFELDT-JAKOB DISEASE (CJD)

 

  • Rare, degenerative, and fatal brain disorder.
  • Belongs to the group of transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs).
  • Results in the rapid deterioration of neurological function.

 

Causes

 

  • Abnormal prion proteins (misfolded) accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage.
  • Can be sporadic, genetic, or acquired through contaminated medical procedures

 

Symptoms

 

  • Rapidly progressive dementia.
  • Muscle stiffness, twitching, and weakness.
  • Behavioral changes, mood swings, and hallucinations.
  • Difficulty walking, speaking, and swallowing

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Based on clinical symptoms, medical history, and neurological examination.
  • Brain imaging and cerebrospinal fluid analysis to rule out other conditions.

 

Treatment

 

  • No cure or specific treatment available.
  • Supportive care to manage symptoms and maintain quality of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cirrhosis: Primarily caused by chronic liver injury due to alcohol abuse, hepatitis, or other liver diseases, and is not related to abnormal protein folding.

 

Option C. Nephritic syndrome: Characterized by inflammation of the glomeruli, leading to hematuria, hypertension, and proteinuria. The condition is generally caused by immune-mediated mechanisms, not by abnormal protein folding.

 

Option D. Sickle cell anemia: While it is caused by a protein mutation, it is not related to the abnormal folding of proteins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a disorder caused by the abnormal folding of prion proteins, leading to severe and fatal brain degeneration.

choices.text: Haemophilus influenzae

questions.text: Pneumonia caused by a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus growing on chocolate agar which is catalase and oxidase-positive. Identify the microorganism. (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Haemophilus influenzae

 

Findings are suggestive of Hemophilus influenza.

 

Hemophilus influenza –

 

  • Slender, short, gram negative rods or coccobacillus
  • Non-Motile, no flagella or pilli
  • Capsules are present and important in pathogenicity.
  • Encapsulated form are coccobacilli, CSF Sample
  • Non-Capsulated are pleomorphic, long, thread, filamentous
  • Fastidious Microorganism

 

Culture:

 

  • Blood Agar: translucent, low, convex or flat pin point colonies, Satellitism.
  • Chocolate Agar: Grayish, Transparent, smooth, low, convex or flat with a slightly splayed out, entire edge, mucoid, pale
  • In liquid medium like Levinthal’s Broth or Filde’s Broth: Uniform Turbidity.

 

Hemophilus influenzae biochemical reactions-

 

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae can cause many kinds of infections. Which can range from mild ear infections to severe diseases, like meningitis. Haemophilus influenzae bacteria most often cause pneumonia, bacteremia, and meningitis mostly in infants and children younger than five years of age.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. E. coli: Although it can cause pneumonia, E. coli is typically a gram-negative rod that grows on MacConkey agar and is not usually pleomorphic. It is catalase-positive but not typically grown on chocolate agar.

 

Option B. Pseudomonas: This genus includes Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is a gram-negative rod that grows on various media, including nutrient agar and MacConkey agar. It is oxidase-positive but does not typically present as pleomorphic.

 

Option D. Actinomyces: This is a gram-positive bacterium and not relevant to this question as it does not fit the gram-negative description.

 

Educational Objective

 

Haemophilus influenzae is a gram-negative pleomorphic bacillus that grows on chocolate agar and is catalase and oxidase-positive. It is a common cause of respiratory infections, including pneumonia, particularly in young children.

 

Additional Information

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presented with generalized fatigue and lethargy. Her general examination revealed a few superficial lymph nodes in the cervical and axillary regions. Labs – TC: 7400, Hb: 12.8 g/dL, and Platelets: 244,000. She had a normal DC and lymph node biopsy revealed architectural distortion, infiltration with cells with indented nucleus, and prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. Immunophenotyping showed CD10 and Bcl2 were positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Follicular Lymphoma

 

The diagnosis of follicular lymphoma is supported by several key features in this patient's presentation and pathology findings:

 

  • Architectural distortion and infiltration with atypical cells: These findings on lymph node biopsy are consistent with follicular lymphoma.
  • Immunophenotyping: The presence of CD10 and Bcl2 positivity is characteristic of follicular lymphoma. CD10 is a marker indicating origin from the germinal center, and Bcl2 positivity suggests the presence of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2, which is a hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkitt Lymphoma: Burkitt lymphoma is associated with c-myc overexpression due to the t(8;14) translocation. It often presents with a high proliferation index and does not typically express Bcl2.

 

Option B. Hodgkin Lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma is characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Sometime, PD1 overexpression. Immunophenotyping usually shows CD15 and CD30 positivity, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Option C. Mantle Cell Lymphoma: Mantle cell lymphoma is characterized by cyclin D1 overexpression due to the t(11;14) translocation. It is usually CD5 and cyclin D1 positive, not CD10 and Bcl2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma often presents with lymphadenopathy and generalized symptoms such as fatigue. Key diagnostic features include CD10 and Bcl2 positivity on immunophenotyping, reflecting its germinal center origin and overexpression of the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl2.

choices.text: 1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only
2 and 3 only
1 and 4 only

questions.text:
Which of the following modalities are used for the diagnosis of placenta accreta? (INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Ultrasonography
  2. MRI
  3. Angiography
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1 and 2 only

 

Explanation:


Ultrasonography and MRI are key modalities used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

  • Ultrasonography (1): This is often the first imaging modality used to diagnose placenta accreta. It helps in visualizing the placental attachment and identifying abnormalities in placental implantation. Color Doppler ultrasonography is particularly useful to assess the blood flow and the vascularity of the placenta, which can indicate abnormal adherence.
  • MRI (2): MRI is used as a complementary imaging tool when ultrasonography results are inconclusive or to provide a more detailed view. It helps in evaluating the depth of placental invasion into the myometrium and can differentiate between placenta accreta, increta, and percreta.
  • Angiography (3): While angiography can provide information about blood vessels and may be used in some cases to evaluate blood flow abnormalities, it is not typically a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta. It may be used in specific scenarios or to plan surgical management, but it is not generally used for initial diagnosis.
  • X-ray (4): X-rays are not used in the diagnosis of placenta accreta due to their lack of sensitivity for soft tissue detail and the potential risk to the fetus. X-rays are not helpful in visualizing the placenta or its adherence to the uterine wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not commonly used for the initial diagnosis of placenta accreta.

 

Option C: Incorrect because it includes Angiography, which is not a primary diagnostic tool for placenta accreta, and it excludes Ultrasonography, which is crucial for diagnosis.

 

Option D: Incorrect because X-ray is not used for diagnosing placenta accreta and does not contribute to the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:


Ultrasonography and MRI are the primary modalities used for diagnosing placenta accreta.

 

Ref: Page no 1982, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with developmental delay, can ride a tricycle, can climb upstairs with alternate feet, can say the name, knows own sex, but cannot narrate a story. What is the developmental age? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 years

 

The developmental age is 3 years.

 

Based on the developmental milestones provided, the child's age can be estimated to be around 3 years old. The child is able to ride a tricycle and climb stairs with alternate feet, which are typical milestones for a 3-year-old child. Additionally, the child is able to say their own name and identify their own sex, which are typical milestones for a 2 to 3-year-old child. However, the child is not able to narrate a story, which is a milestone typically seen in 4 to 5-year-old children. Therefore, overall, the child's developmental age is estimated to be around 3 years old.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 4 years: A child can narrate stories by 4 years

 

Option C. 5 years: By 5 years child can ask meaning of words

 

Option D. 2 years: 2 years cannot tell his full name, age and sex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child's developmental age can be estimated by comparing their abilities to typical developmental milestones; in this case, a child who can ride a tricycle and climb stairs with alternating feet is likely around 3 years old.

questions.text:
Which of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Bard-Parker blade
  2. Doyen's retractor
  3. Cusco's speculum
  4. Allis forceps
  5. Shirodkar's uterine clamp
  6. Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4, 6

 

Explanation:

 

Instruments used in a cesarean section

 

  • BP handle
  • Allis forceps
  • Artery forceps
  • Doyen retractor
  • Green Armitage forceps
  • Metzenbaum scissors

 

Among the options

 

  • Cusco’s speculum has no role in LSCA It is a vaginal self-retaining speculum with two blades
  • Shirodkar’s uterine clamp is used in gynecological procedures to hold the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify that Bard-Parker blade, Doyen's retractor, Allis forceps, and Green Armytage forceps are essential instruments used in a cesarean section, while Cusco's speculum and Shirodkar's uterine clamp are not used in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page no 756

choices.text: Optic nerve (II CN)
Oculomotor nerve (III CN)
Abducens nerve (VI CN)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of blurred vision and difficulty seeing objects clearly, particularly in her right eye. On examination, her eye movements are intact, but visual acuity is significantly reduced. A detailed assessment reveals that the nerve responsible for her symptoms is not involved in controlling eye movements but plays a key role in transmitting visual information. Which of the following nerves is not involved in the movement of the eyeball?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Optic nerve (II CN)

 

Explanation:

 

The nerve marked as 'A' is the optic nerve (II CN), which is not involved in the movement of the eyeball. The optic nerve is primarily responsible for carrying visual information from the retina to the brain, making it crucial for vision. However, it does not directly control eye movements, unlike other cranial nerves involved in eye muscle innervation. Its role is purely sensory, allowing the brain to receive and process visual input, which is essential for sight but does not influence the position or movement of the eyeball.

 

 

Other Options:

 

B. Oculomotor nerve (III CN): The oculomotor nerve controls most of the eye muscles, including the superior, medial, and inferior rectus muscles and the inferior oblique muscle, playing a major role in eye movement.

 

C. Abducens nerve (VI CN): The abducens nerve is responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye, moving it outward.

 

D. Trochlear nerve (IV CN): The trochlear nerve innervates the superior oblique muscle, allowing the eye to move downward and laterally, contributing to coordinated eye movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The optic nerve (II CN) is responsible for transmitting visual information from the retina to the brain and is not involved in eye movement. The oculomotor, trochlear, and abducens nerves control different muscles that allow precise movements of the eyeball.

choices.text: No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman is admitted with dengue hemorrhagic fever. After several days of management, her condition stabilizes, and the medical team considers discharging her. Which of the following is an appropriate criterion to decide the discharge of a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) After the return of appetite

 

  • The appropriate criteria for discharging a patient recovering from dengue hemorrhagic shock include several clinical signs indicating recovery and stability.
  • One crucial criterion is the return of appetite, which signifies a significant clinical improvement and recovery from the acute phase of the illness.

 

SIGNS OF RECOVERY: 

 

  • Stable pulse, blood pressure and breathing rate
  • Normal temperature
  • No evidence of external or internal bleeding
  • Return of appetite
  • No vomiting
  • Good urine output 
  • Stable haematocrit 
  • Convalescent confluent petechiae rash

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. No episode of fever for more than 24 hours with paracetamol: The absence of fever should be without the use of antipyretics like paracetamol.

 

Option C. Urine output more than 200 ml: This is not a standard criterion; adequate urine output should be considered, but specific volume thresholds are not typically used.

 

Option D. After 24 hours from recovery of shock: Recovery from shock should be sustained, and other criteria like appetite and clinical stability are more reliable indicators.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRITERIA FOR DISCHARGING PATIENTS: 

 

  • Absence of fever for at least 24 hours without the use of anti-fever therapy
  • Return of appetite
  • Visible clinical improvement 
  • Good urine output 
  • Minimum of three days after recovery from shock
  • No respiratory distress from pleural effusion and no ascites
  • Platelet count of more than 50,000/mm

questions.text:
Galactomannan in serum is seen in: (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. Invasive aspergillosis
  2. Systemic candidiasis
  3. Mucormycosis
  4. Cryptococcosis
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 Only

 

The galactomannan assay is used for the diagnosis of invasive Aspergillosis

 

Galactomannan (GM) belongs to a group of polysaccharides which consist of a mannose backbone and a variable number of galactofuran side chains. GM makes up a major part of the cell wall of Aspergillus spp. These galactofuranose-containing polysaccharides vary are secreted in vivo by the fungus during invasive growth. In recent years, the detection of galactofuranose-containing antigens, including GM, has been used for diagnosing invasive aspergillosis (IA).

 

The most commonly used method to determine GM in serum and broncho-alveolar lavage (BAL) fluid is a double sandwich enzyme-linked immune assay

 

Other Fungal Infections:

 

2. Systemic Candidiasis: Does not typically involve the release of galactomannan.

 

3. Mucormycosis: Caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, which do not produce  galactomannan. It has beta-D-Glucans and mannans that can be used for diagnosis of invasive candidiasis.

 

4. Cryptococcosis: Caused by Cryptococcus species, and the detection of its polysaccharide capsule antigen (cryptococcal antigen) is used for diagnosis, not galactomannan.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The galactomannan assay is specifically used to diagnose invasive aspergillosis, and the presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of this fungal infection.

choices.text: Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

questions.text: Which of the following is the etiology of the Werner syndrome with premature aging?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Short telomere with damaged DNA and loss of helicase

 

This is the correct explanation for the etiology of Werner syndrome. Individuals with Werner syndrome have mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a helicase enzyme involved in DNA repair and maintenance. These mutations lead to the loss of helicase function and result in the accumulation of DNA damage and shortened telomeres, contributing to premature aging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased length of telomere: This option is not the cause of Werner syndrome. In fact, individuals with Werner syndrome have shortened telomeres, not increased length. Telomeres are the protective caps at the end of chromosomes, and their shortening is associated with aging and age-related diseases.

 

Option C. Increased advanced glycation end products: Advanced glycation end products (AGEs) are associated with various age-related conditions, but they are not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. While AGEs can contribute to cellular damage, they are not the central mechanism behind this syndrome.

 

Option D. Decreased lipid peroxidation: Decreased lipid peroxidation is not the primary cause of Werner syndrome. Lipid peroxidation refers to the oxidative damage to lipids (fats), and although oxidative stress is involved in aging, it is not the primary driver of Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Werner syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by premature aging. It is caused by mutations in the WRN gene, which encodes a protein called Werner syndrome ATP-dependent helicase (WRN). The WRN protein is involved in DNA repair, maintenance of genome stability, and telomere maintenance. One of the other functions of this protein is DNA helicase.

 

In Werner syndrome, there is a loss of function of the WRN protein, leading to problems with DNA repair and telomere maintenance. Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of chromosomes, and they shorten with each cell division. In Werner syndrome, there is accelerated telomere shortening, and this contributes to premature aging. There is also increased risk of cancer.

 

Ref: Harper’s 31st/e pg. 370

questions.text: Noninvasive test to detect hepatic fibrosis include? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibro test

 

The FibroTest, also known as the Fibro test, is a noninvasive, blood-based test designed specifically to detect hepatic fibrosis. This test calculates the degree of liver fibrosis using a combination of several serum biochemical markers including haptoglobin, bilirubin, gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT), apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin. It evaluates liver damage and fibrosis by measuring these markers, which are affected by liver function and architecture changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspartate aminotransferases /platelet ratio (APRI): Incorrect as it is primarily used to estimate the likelihood or severity of fibrosis rather than to directly detect it. It correlates with the degree of liver fibrosis but is less specific.

 

Option C. Forns index: Incorrect for the same reason as APRI. The Forns index is used to assess the risk of developing liver fibrosis based on variables including age, platelet count, cholesterol levels, and GGT, but it does not directly measure fibrosis.

 

Option D. Serum laminin & serum hyaluronidase: Incorrect as these are not standard tests for directly detecting hepatic fibrosis; they can indicate changes in extracellular matrix turnover but are less specific and commonly used compared to the FibroTest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibro test is a sensitive test to detect hepatic fibrosis. It is a multiparameter blood test which incorporate haptoglobin, bilirubin, GGT, apolipoprotein A1, and alpha-2 macroglobulin.

 

Test for estimating risk developing hepatic fibrosis:

 

  1. AST/platelet ratio
  2. Forns index
  3. Fib-4
  4. Cirrhosis determinant score.

 

Test for detecting hepatic fibrosis: Fibro test.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence 5'GATCTAC3'. What is the base sequence of RNA product? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5'GUAGAUC3'

 

Explanation:

 

You're given the template strand of DNA:


5′–GATCTAC–3′

 

But remember:

 

  • Transcription reads the DNA template in the 3′ → 5′ direction
  • So we must first reverse the strand to get its 3′ → 5′ orientation
    3′–CATAGTC–5′

 

Now, perform complementary base pairing to make the RNA strand (synthesized 5′ to 3′):

 

 

So the RNA product is:


5′–GUAGAUC–3′

 

Educational Objective

 

The complementary base pairing rules are:

 

  • Adenine (A) pairs with Uracil (U) in RNA.
  • Thymine (T) pairs with Adenine (A).
  • Cytosine (C) pairs with Guanine (G).
  • Guanine (G) pairs with Cytosine (C).

 

The RNA product formed during transcription is complementary to the DNA template strand and follows the base-pairing rules with uracil replacing thymine.

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the incorrect pairing. The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery doesn't primarily supply the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly supplied by branches from the vertebral arteries, such as the posterior meningeal artery.
  • The meningeal branches of Internal Carotid artery supply the anterior cranial fossa 
     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the most significant arterial supply to the dura mater. After entering the skull through the foramen spinosum, it typically divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies the dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option B. Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal artery is a smaller branch that originates from the maxillary artery. It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale. This artery supplies the dura of the middle cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries arise from the ophthalmic artery (a branch of the internal carotid artery). These arteries have meningeal branches that supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the region overlying the ethmoid bone and the frontal bone's adjacent parts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Summary of Blood supply to Dura

  1. Anterior cranial fossa
    1. By ethmoidal artery which is the branch of opthalmic artery which in tern is the branch of Internal carotid artery 
    2. Middle meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  2. Middle cranial fossa
    1. Accessory meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  3. Posterior Cranial fossa
    1. Meningeal branches from the branches of the vertebral artery.
       
  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) meningeal branch supply blood to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries, which run along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull and supply the following regions.

questions.text: Which organism moves transcellularly by utilizing actin filaments? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Listeria

 

Explanation:

 

Listeria monocytogenes moves within and between cells by polymerizing host actin filaments, forming "comet tails" that propel the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli): Invades intestinal cells but does not utilize actin filaments for intracellular movement.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Invades cells but moves intracellularly via different mechanisms, not actin-based motility.

 

Option D. Vibrio: Known for cholera; does not utilize actin for intracellular movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Listeria monocytogenes uniquely utilizes actin filaments for intracellular movement, a key feature distinguishing it from other enteric pathogens like EIEC, Salmonella, and Vibrio.

questions.text: A patient with a known case of chronic plaque psoriasis with more than 50% skin involvement presents to you. Which of the following will you not recommend? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oral steroids

 

Oral/systemic steroids are not used in the management of chronic plaque psoriasis. Topical steroids may be used.

 

The only clear-cut indication for systemic steroids is pregnancy, as they are contraindicated in all other forms of psoriasis due to the risk of sudden withdrawal causing severe pustular or erythrodermic psoriasis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Oral methotrexate: Methotrexate is an antimetabolite and immune modulator commonly used as a systemic treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It is effective in reducing the proliferation of skin cells and has anti-inflammatory properties.

 

Option B. NB UVB (Narrowband Ultraviolet B): NB UVB phototherapy is a well-established treatment for moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. It works by reducing skin cell proliferation and modulating the immune system.

 

Option D. Oral cyclosporine: Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that suppresses the immune system and is used for severe psoriasis. It is effective for quick control of the disease due to its potent immunosuppressive effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oral steroids are not recommended for the long-term treatment of chronic plaque psoriasis due to the risk of disease exacerbation upon steroid withdrawal and the potential for serious side effects with long-term use.

 

Drug of choice for different types of psoriasis:

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 35.22, 35.35, 35.37

questions.text:
What would be seen if the central part of the cord was involved? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs.
  2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs.
  3. Bladder and bowel involvement.
  4. Posterior tract involvement.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 and 3

 

Central cord lesions, such as those seen in conditions like syringomyelia and intramedullary tumors, present with a distinct pattern of neurological deficits due to the anatomical arrangement of the spinal tracts.

 

1. LMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and UMN of lower limbs: This pattern is common in central cord syndromes, where there is damage to the anterior horn cells leading to lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions in the upper limbs. As the condition progresses, upper motor neuron (UMN) signs may appear in the lower limbs due to the involvement of the corticospinal tract.

 

3. Bladder and bowel involvement: Central cord lesions can affect autonomic functions leading to bladder and bowel dysfunction, especially in cases of extensive or progressive lesions like intramedullary tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

2. UMN lesion of upper limbs and trunk and LMN of lower limbs: This pattern is not typical for central cord syndromes. Usually, the upper limbs show LMN signs due to the involvement of the anterior horn cells, and the lower limbs show UMN signs.

 

4. Posterior tract involvement: Posterior tracts, which carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioception, are usually spared in central cord syndromes. These tracts are located more dorsally in the spinal cord, away from the central lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Central cord lesions, such as syringomyelia, typically present with LMN signs in the upper limbs, UMN signs in the lower limbs, and can involve bladder and bowel dysfunction, but they do not typically affect the posterior tracts

questions.text: You're rotating in the infection control unit of a tertiary care hospital in Chennai. As part of your duties, you have been assigned to educate the staff about the importance of precautionary measures and isolation techniques for various conditions. While discussing droplet precautions, one of the staff inquired about the diseases for which such precautions are necessary. Which of the following conditions does NOT typically require precautionary measures and isolation due to droplet infection? [AIIMS NOV 2018]
