questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Localized varicella zoster

 

  • Droplet precautions and isolation are unnecessary for localized varicella-zoster, as this virus is exclusively transmitted through direct contact.
  • When varicella-zoster remains confined to a patient with a fully functioning immune system and can be effectively contained or covered, there is no need for droplet precautions.
  • However, if varicella becomes disseminated in any patient, it necessitates both airborne and contact precautions.
  • On the other hand, diseases like diphtheria, pertussis, and mycoplasma are transmitted via droplets and, therefore, demand droplet precautions and isolation measures.
  • These precautions include the use of masks, gowns, gloves, and protective eye gear when delivering direct patient care.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pertussis: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Option B. Diphtheria: Requires droplet precautions as it is spread through respiratory droplets.

 

Option D. Mycoplasma pneumonia: Requires droplet precautions due to transmission via respiratory droplets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Localized varicella zoster does not require droplet precautions as it is transmitted through direct contact, while conditions like pertussis, diphtheria, and mycoplasma pneumonia require droplet precautions due to their transmission via respiratory droplets.

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which investigation can be detrimental to this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. MRI

 

  • MRI can cause movements of an intraocular foreign body (OFB) if it is magnetic and is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies.
  • The most common foreign bodies to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel.
  • Foreign bodies entering the eye may cause damage by mechanical effects, introduction of infection, or reacting with the intraocular tissues.
  • Localization of intraocular foreign body can be done through:
    1. Radiographic: Limbal ring method, which is the simplest but sparingly employed technique.
    2. Ultrasonographic: Can tell the position of even non-radio-opaque foreign bodies.
    3. CT scan: Presently the best method of intraocular foreign body localization, providing cross-sectional images with superior sensitivity and specificity than plain radiography and ultrasonography.

 

  • A foreign body should always be removed unless it is inert and probably sterile, little damage has been done to vision, or the process of removal will destroy sight.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT: CT scan is highly effective for detecting and localizing metallic foreign bodies. It provides detailed cross-sectional images without the risks associated with MRI.

 

Option C. X-ray: X-ray can detect metallic foreign bodies and is a safe initial imaging modality. However, it is less sensitive than CT.

 

Option D. B mode scan: B mode ultrasound can help localize non-radio-opaque foreign bodies and assess intraocular damage. It is safe and commonly used when MRI is contraindicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI is contraindicated for patients with suspected metallic foreign bodies in the eye due to the risk of movement and further injury caused by the magnetic fields.

choices.text: 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D
1-D, 2-F, 3-E, 4-C
1-D, 2-A, 3-C 4-E
1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their ocular adverse effects?(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1-D, 2-C, 3-F, 4-E

 

The following are the drugs and their associated ocular adverse effects:

 

  1. Amiodarone: This drug is known to cause corneal deposits (cornea verticillata) and optic neuritis. The correct match for Amiodarone is D (Optic neuritis).
  2. Hydroxychloroquine: This drug is associated with bull’s eye maculopathy, a specific type of retinopathy. Therefore, Hydroxychloroquine is correctly matched with C (Retinopathy).
  3. Systemic steroids: When given topically, systemic steroids can cause open-angle glaucoma. However, when given systemically, they are known to cause posterior subcapsular cataract. Thus, systemic steroids are best matched with F (Cataract).
  4. Digoxin: This drug can cause yellow vision, a condition where the patient perceives a yellow tint in their vision. Hence, Digoxin is correctly matched with E (Yellow vision).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ocular adverse-effects of drugs:

 

  • Amiodarone: Corneal deposits (cornea verticallata) Optic neuritis
  • Hydroxychloroquine: Bull’s eye maculopathy (retinopathy).
  • Systemic steroids: Given topically – cause Open angle Glaucoma; Given systemically – cause Posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Digoxin: Yellow vision

 

Reference: - KDT 8TH/880, 318, 560, Goodman Gilman 13th/  564

choices.text: Rectangular and flat
Triangular on each side, forming a diamond shape together
Circular and small

questions.text: A 22-year-old physical therapist is reviewing the anatomy of the upper back muscles while treating a patient with shoulder discomfort. She is particularly interested in understanding the shape and functional anatomy of the muscle that spans from the back of the neck down to the mid-back, attaching to the shoulder blade and clavicle. She describes the muscle as broad and superficially positioned, covering a large portion of the upper back. Which of the following best describes the shape of this muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Triangular on each side, forming a diamond shape together

 

Explanation:

 

The trapezius muscle is a large, paired muscle that spans the back of the neck and thorax. Each trapezius muscle is triangular, with its base along the spine and its apex pointing towards the shoulder. When the left and right trapezius muscles are considered together, they form a diamond shape, resembling the shape of a trapezoid, which is how the muscle gets its name. This unique shape allows it to perform multiple functions, including elevating, retracting, and rotating the scapula.

 

 

Other Options:

 

A. Rectangular and flat: This description does not match the trapezius muscle. The trapezius is not rectangular; rather, it has a distinctive triangular shape on each side and forms a diamond shape when both sides are viewed together.

 

C. Circular and small: The trapezius is neither circular nor small. It is a large, broad muscle that covers a significant area of the upper back and neck, contributing to the mobility and stability of the scapula and shoulder.

 

D. Cylindrical and narrow: This description is incorrect for the trapezius muscle, which is broad and flat rather than cylindrical. Cylindrical muscles are typically seen in limb muscles, not in the broad, flat muscles of the back like the trapezius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trapezius muscle is triangular on each side of the body and forms a diamond shape when viewed together, which contributes to its name. It plays a critical role in movements of the scapula, including elevation, retraction, and rotation, making it essential for shoulder function.

questions.text: Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to the plasma by binding to? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferroportin

 

Iron absorption is regulated by hepcidin, a small circulating peptide that is synthesized and released from the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels.

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocyte to plasma by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, as hepcidin levels rise, iron becomes trapped within duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost as these cells are sloughed. Thus, when the body is replete with iron, high hepcidin levels inhibit its absorption into the blood.

 

Conversely, with low body stores of iron, hepcidin synthesis falls and this in turn facilitates iron absorption. By inhibiting ferroportin, hepcidin not only reduces iron uptake from enterocytes but also suppresses iron release from macrophages, which are an important source of the iron that is used by erythroid precursors to make hemoglobin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: Transferrin is a plasma protein that binds iron in the bloodstream and transports it to various tissues. It is not directly involved in the inhibition of iron transfer by hepcidin.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron within cells, particularly in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow. It does not play a direct role in the transfer of iron from enterocytes to the plasma.

 

Option D. Divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1): DMT1 is responsible for transporting iron across the apical membrane of enterocytes into the cell. It is not the target of hepcidin's inhibitory action.

 

Educational objective:

 

Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from enterocytes to the plasma by binding to ferroportin, leading to its internalization and degradation.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg no. 1231

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with fever, weight loss came to the hospital. On examination, he was pale and had significant lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow histology of the person is as given below. Your diagnosis is: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia

 

The given scenario with bone marrow histology showing lymphoblasts (condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, scanty agranular cytoplasm) is suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

 

 

PBF Findings in acute lymphoblastic (ALL). The cell is large, with round to convoluted nuclei having high N/C ratio and no cytoplasmic granularity.

 

ALL is more common in childhood.

 

Clinical features of ALL include:

 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute monocytic leukemia and Option B. Acute myelomonocytic leukemia: These leukemias typically present with different morphologic features, including monoblasts and myeloblasts, which show different cytological characteristics such as cytoplasmic granularity and different nuclear morphology.

 

Option D. Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML): JMML is a rare childhood leukemia with a different clinical presentation, often including hepatosplenomegaly and elevated monocyte counts, and it does not present with the lymphoblast morphology seen in ALL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in children is characterized by the presence of lymphoblasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood, along with clinical features of bone marrow failure and organ infiltration by malignant cells.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 1113

choices.text: Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception
Absence of fine motor movement of fingers
Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Absence of ipsilateral arm proprioception

 

Explanation

 

The above clinical scenario depicts transection of the spinal cord in the lateral aspect of the dorsal column would affect the fasciculus cuneatus. This lesion would result in absence of ipsilateral proprioception of the arm.

 

 

The fibers in the dorsal column are arranged in such a manner that the sacral segments are positioned most medially and those from the cervical segments are positioned most laterally.

 

These are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus gracilis - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb
  • ﻿﻿Fasciculus cuneatus - carrying sensations from the ipsilateral upper limb.

 

Fasciculus Gracilis and Cuneatus functions:

 

  1. Fine touch
  2. Tactile localization
  3. Tactile discrimination
  4. Vibration

 

This patient with an injury to the lateral part of the cervical cord's dorsal column tract will have damaged fasciculus cuneatus. This would result in loss of touch, vibration, and proprioception in the arm of the same side of the lesion.

 

function below the level of injury. The clue to solving this question is that the question mentions that the damage is to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Absence of ipsilateral lower limb proprioception: This would be seen if the fasciculus gracilis was affected, which is responsible for carrying sensations from the ipsilateral lower limb.

 

Option B. Absence of fine motor movement of fingers: This would be a result of damage to the corticospinal tract, which carries motor information.

 

Option D. Absence of contralateral lower limb proprioception: Proprioception is carried by the dorsal column pathway, and it is affected ipsilaterally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract in the cervical spine region results in the loss of ipsilateral arm proprioception due to the involvement of the fasciculus cuneatus. This emphasizes the importance of the dorsal column in carrying proprioceptive and fine tactile information from the upper limbs.

 

Additional Information

 

Brown Sequard Syndrome (Hemi-sectioning of spinal cord)

 

  • I/L loss of Fine touch
  • C/L loss of Pain & Temperature
  • I/L loss of Proprioception
  • I/L motor paralysis

questions.text: Most potent biological Estrogen: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Estradiol

 

Explanation:

 

Estrogens are a group of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the regulation of the female reproductive system and secondary sexual characteristics. Among the different forms of estrogen, estradiol (E2) is the most potent and biologically active. Estradiol is primarily produced by the ovaries and is the dominant form of estrogen during the reproductive years.

 

Estradiol binds with the highest affinity to estrogen receptors compared to other forms like estrone and estriol, which is why it exerts the most potent biological effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is less potent than estradiol and is the primary form of estrogen after menopause. It has a weaker affinity for estrogen receptors and thus, exerts less biological activity.

 

Option C. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three primary estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy and has the least biological activity due to its low affinity for estrogen receptors.

 

Option D. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogens are a mixture of several types of estrogens, typically used in hormone replacement therapy. They are not as biologically potent as estradiol when considered individually.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estradiol is the most potent biological estrogen.

questions.text: Which of the following layers is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial thickness burn? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Papillary dermis

 

The papillary dermis is a layer of the skin that lies just below the epidermis. Blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns occurs within this layer, as it is the point where the burn has affected both the epidermis and the upper portion of the dermis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidermis: The epidermis is the outermost layer of the skin. In superficial partial thickness burns, this layer is typically damaged, but blister formation occurs slightly deeper within the skin.

 

Option B. Subcutaneous tissue: The subcutaneous tissue is located beneath the dermis and is not typically involved in blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns.

 

Option D. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is located deeper in the skin and is not primarily associated with blister formation in superficial partial thickness burns. Blister formation occurs closer to the surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The papillary dermis is involved in blister formation in a superficial partial-thickness burn.

 

First-degree burns involve only the epidermis, with pain, redness, and mild swelling.

 

Second-degree burns involve the epidermis and some parts of the dermis (also known as partial-thickness burns). Further classified as-

 

  • Superficial second degree or superficial partial-thickness burn - involves the upper part of the dermis (papillary) and shows pain, blisters, and severe swelling.
  • Deep second degree or deep partial-thickness burn - extends deeper up to the reticular layer of the dermis and appears paler and more mottled, does not blanch to touch, but remains painful to pinprick.

 

Third-degree or full-thickness burns involve the complete thickness of the dermis and subcutaneous tissue.

choices.text: Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD
Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: All are true about Barrett esophagus except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increases risk of squamous cell carcinoma

 

Not squamous cell carcinoma, but esophageal adenocarcinoma is the cancer risk that is increased by Barrett's esophagus.

 

Barrett's esophagus is a premalignant condition.

 

Barrett's epithelium (columnar metaplasia), dysplasia, carcinoma in situ, and esophageal adenocarcinoma develop sequentially from one another.

 

Microscopically, goblet cells are shown to have taken the place of the squamous esophageal epithelium (intestinal metaplasia).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complication of chronic GERD: True, as Barrett’s esophagus commonly develops as a response to the damage from chronic acid reflux.

 

Option B. Seen in 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD: True, as approximately 10% of GERD patients develop Barrett's esophagus.

 

Option D. Intestinal metaplasia: True, and is a defining characteristic of Barrett’s esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus increases the risk of esophageal adenocarcinoma due to the transformation of squamous cells to columnar cells, not squamous cell carcinoma.

choices.text: Lateral plate mesoderm

questions.text: A III-year resident is discussing a case of 32-year-old pregnant woman with interns and explaining the formation of the urinary system and mentions a crucial embryonic structure that gives rise to the ureter, renal pelvis, and other parts of the collecting system of the kidney. He points out the importance of this development for proper kidney function. From which embryonic structure does the ureteric bud develop?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct

 

Explanation:

 

The ureteric bud develops from the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct, an essential structure in early embryonic development. This duct plays a critical role in forming parts of the urinary and reproductive systems. The ureteric bud emerges from the mesonephric duct and undergoes repeated branching, eventually giving rise to the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting tubules of the kidney. The interaction between the ureteric bud and the metanephric blastema is crucial for kidney development, as the metanephros forms the functional units of the definitive kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

A. Paraxial mesoderm: The paraxial mesoderm is responsible for forming somites, which differentiate into the axial skeleton, skeletal muscles, and dermis of the skin. It does not contribute to the development of the urinary system or the formation of the ureteric bud.

 

C. Lateral plate mesoderm: This structure splits into somatic and splanchnic layers and plays a role in forming the heart, blood vessels, and body wall components, but it is not involved in the formation of the ureteric bud or the urinary system.

 

D. Genital ridge: The genital ridge forms the gonads (ovaries and testes) but does not participate in the development of the urinary system. It is primarily involved in the formation of reproductive structures, not the ureteric bud.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ureteric bud develops from the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and plays a critical role in forming the collecting system of the kidneys, including the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting tubules. This process is vital for the proper development of the urinary system, driven by interactions with the metanephric blastema to form the definitive kidney.

questions.text: A patient with history of alcoholism presented with right hypochondriac pain and fever. He had an episode of diarrhoea 1 week prior. USG abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25 cc in right lobe. What is the next step in management?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical management

 

  • This patient with USG revealing abscess in the liver most likely has an amebic liver abscess. Since next best is asked, medical management should be started first.

 

Amoebic liver abscess:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PAIR: PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Injection, Re-aspiration) is more commonly used for hydatid cysts and not the first-line treatment for amoebic liver abscesses.

 

Option B. Surgery: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where there is no response to medical treatment or complications arise.

 

Option D. Percutaneous drainage: This can be considered if the abscess is large, at risk of rupture, or if there is no response to medical management. However, initial treatment should be medical management with antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For amoebic liver abscess, initial management should always begin with medical therapy using metronidazole, chloroquine, and diloxanide furoate.
  •  Drainage or aspiration is considered based on the size and risk of rupture of the abscess.

questions.text: In a patient with renal stones, the following crystals suggest what etiology? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triple phosphate

 

The image provided in the question shows crystals that are described as "coffin-lid" shaped. These crystals are characteristic of triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones. Struvite stones are commonly associated with urinary tract infections caused by urease-producing bacteria, which raise the urine pH and promote the formation of these crystals.

 

  • Triple Phosphate Crystals (Struvite): These crystals have a distinctive coffin-lid shape, which is clearly depicted in the image. They are typically seen in alkaline urine and are associated with infections, especially those caused by urease-producing organisms like Proteus, Klebsiella, or Pseudomonas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Uric Acid: Uric acid crystals are usually rhomboid or rosette-shaped. They form in acidic urine and are not associated with the coffin-lid appearance shown in the image.

 

Option C. Calcium Oxalate Monohydrate: These crystals have a dumbbell or ovoid shape, not resembling the coffin-lid appearance in the image.

 

Option D. Calcium Oxalate Dihydrate: These crystals are typically envelope-shaped, resembling a square with a diagonal cross. While they might be confused with the coffin-lid shape, they are distinctively different.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coffin-lid shaped crystals in a urine analysis are indicative of triple phosphate stones, commonly associated with urinary tract infections and alkaline urine.

questions.text: An elderly man with diabetic nephropathy presented to the emergency department with palpitations and chest discomfort. The ECG revealed large T-waves. Laboratory tests revealed elevated potassium levels. Which of the following drugs can cause intracellular movement of potassium? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epinephrine

 

Beta 2 agonists (like Salbutamol and Epinephrine) and Insulin help in the intracellular movement of K+. These drugs therefore can decrease serum potassium levels.

 

The drugs that can be used in the management of acute hyperkalemia are:

 

  • Salbutamol
  • Glucose + Insulin (DOC)
  • Calcium gluconate

 

In case of chronic hyperkalemia, K+ binding resins like Patiromer and Polystyrene sulfonate can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucagon: Glucagon primarily works to increase blood glucose levels by promoting glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. It does not play a significant role in shifting potassium intracellularly.

 

Option C. Atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic drug that blocks muscarinic receptors. It is not involved in potassium homeostasis or its intracellular movement.

 

Option D. Lactic acid: Lactic acid does not facilitate the intracellular movement of potassium. In fact, metabolic acidosis (which can be associated with elevated lactic acid levels) tends to cause potassium to move out of cells into the extracellular space, exacerbating hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-2 agonists, such as Epinephrine, are effective in promoting the intracellular movement of potassium, thereby reducing serum potassium levels in cases of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

Alcohol abuse is strongly associated with the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Alcohol and its metabolites, acetaldehyde, have a toxic effect on the myocardium which leads to the development of dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy causes include:

 

Acquisition of causes

 

  • The most frequent causes of myocarditis worldwide are infectious (particularly coxsackievirus B) and non-infectious myocarditis.
  • In India, alcohol is the most frequent culprit.
  • Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PCM) and pregnancy-associated cardiomyopathy (PACM) (PPCM)
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy brought on by stress

 

Meth-related:

 

  • Doxycycline (anthracycline)
  • Cyclophosphamide and trastuzumab

 

A lack of nutrition:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency; Keshan disease (selenium); Beriberi (thiamine);
  • Endocrine: acromegaly, diabetes mellitus, hypo- and hyperthyroidism
  • Additional
  • Toxicity of cobalt, Heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, lithium)

 

Genetic factors (50%):

 

Haemochromatosis; Duchenne muscular dystrophy; Becker's muscular dystrophy; cardiac myocyte titin gene mutation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericarditis: While alcohol can have widespread effects on the body, it is not directly associated with the development of pericarditis.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy: This condition involves the thickening of the heart muscle, primarily due to genetic causes, and is not directly linked to alcohol use.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Generally caused by infections (particularly viral), autoimmune disorders, or toxic exposures, but not specifically by alcohol.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dilated cardiomyopathy associated with alcohol abuse reflects the cumulative detrimental effects of alcohol on heart structure and function, compounded by nutritional deficiencies and genetic factors, making it a critical concern in chronic alcohol consumers.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe, tearing chest pain radiating to his back. The pain began abruptly while he was at rest. On examination, his blood pressure is significantly higher in the right arm compared to the left. Suspecting an aortic dissection, the physician orders a CT angiogram of the chest. The radiologist reviews the cross-sectional image and notes the presence of the aortic arch and its branches. At which anatomical level is this cross-sectional image most likely taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. T3-T4

 

Explanation:

 

The cross-section in the image is at the level of T3-T4, identified by the prominent aortic arch and its major branches, including the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. The large opening for the aortic arch is a key feature seen at this level, distinguishing it from other thoracic sections. These three smaller vascular structures are characteristic of this anatomical region, indicating that the image was taken at the T3-T4 vertebral level. This level is specifically significant as it marks the location of the aortic arch, a crucial landmark in thoracic imaging.

 

 

Other Options:

 

A. T1-T2: At the T1-T2 level, the cross-section would primarily show structures such as the trachea and major veins like the brachiocephalic veins and superior vena cava. The aortic arch and its branches are not visible at this higher thoracic level, making it an incorrect choice.

 

C. T5-T6: At the T5-T6 level, the descending aorta is seen instead of the aortic arch. The characteristic branches of the aortic arch are not visible, as they lie superiorly at T3-T4. This makes the T5-T6 level incompatible with the provided image.

 

D. T7-T8: The T7-T8 level includes the descending aorta, esophagus, and other thoracic structures, without the presence of the aortic arch or its primary branches. This level is located further down the thorax and lacks the distinguishing features of the T3-T4 section.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T3-T4 level of the thorax can be identified on imaging by the presence of the aortic arch and its major branches, including the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. Recognizing these structures is essential for accurately identifying thoracic cross-sectional levels, especially in evaluating acute aortic syndromes and other thoracic pathologies.

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old patient is admitted to the hospital with septic shock. The physician decides to administer vasopressors to manage the patient's condition. The patient also requires multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access. A central venous catheter is inserted into the patient's internal jugular vein. Which of the following statements are true regarding central and peripheral venous access and their associated complications? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.
  2. Flushing with isotonic saline and heparin can maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.
  3. If an arteriovenous fistula is present in a limb, peripheral venous access should be avoided in that same limb.
  4. Vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Statement 1 is true as phlebitis is the most common complication associated with peripheral venous access.

 

Statement 2 is also true as flushing with isotonic saline and heparin is used to maintain patency in both central and peripheral venous catheters.

 

Statement 3 is true as the presence of an arteriovenous fistula in a limb is a relative contraindication for peripheral venous access in that same limb.

 

Statement 4 is also true as vasopressors used for septic shock are typically administered via a central venous catheter to avoid limb ischemia.

 

In this clinical case, the patient's septic shock required vasopressors, and multiple infusions that are not compatible with peripheral intravenous access, leading to the insertion of a central venous catheter into the internal jugular vein. To prevent or avoid the formation of thrombus in venous catheters, the solutions used include 0.9% sodium chloride, heparin, vitamin C, and sodium citrate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septic shock is a life-threatening medical condition that occurs as a result of a severe infection leading to a systemic inflammatory response. It is characterized by a combination of infection, low blood pressure (hypotension), and organ dysfunction. Here are some key points about septic shock:

 

  1. Infection: Septic shock typically begins with an infection, often caused by bacteria, but it can also result from fungal or viral infections. Common sources of infection include lung infections (pneumonia), urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and skin infections.
  2. Systemic Inflammatory Response: In response to the infection, the body's immune system initiates a widespread inflammatory response. This response can become dysregulated, leading to an exaggerated release of inflammatory molecules (cytokines) into the bloodstream.
  3. Hypotension: One of the hallmark features of septic shock is low blood pressure (hypotension). The inflammation and vasodilation caused by the infection can lead to a drop in blood pressure, which can result in inadequate blood flow to vital organs.
  4. Organ Dysfunction: As blood pressure drops and organs receive less oxygen and nutrients, multiple organ systems can begin to fail. This can lead to dysfunction in the heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and other organs. Organ dysfunction is a critical component of septic shock and contributes to its high mortality rate.
  5. Symptoms: Symptoms of septic shock can include fever or hypothermia (low body temperature), rapid heart rate, rapid breathing, confusion, altered mental status, and signs of organ dysfunction such as respiratory distress, kidney failure, or liver dysfunction.
  6. Treatment: The treatment of septic shock is a medical emergency and involves aggressive interventions. It typically includes antibiotics to treat the underlying infection, intravenous fluids to maintain blood pressure, vasopressor medications to constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure, and supportive care in an intensive care unit (ICU).

questions.text: Which of the following is the Miami criteria for intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) measurement? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Half fall in 10 min

 

Half fall in 10 min: This is correct. The Miami Criteria for successful parathyroidectomy require a drop in PTH level of more than 50% from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the removal of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue.

 

The Miami Criteria, also known as the Miami Intraoperative Criteria, refers to a set of guidelines used to confirm successful removal of hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue during parathyroidectomy. The criteria are based on intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels.

 

According to the Miami Criteria, a successful parathyroidectomy is indicated if there is a drop in PTH level of more than 50% (half) from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the adenoma. This significant decrease indicates that the source of excess PTH production has been successfully removed.

 

The utility of this approach is that it allows for immediate feedback during surgery about whether all hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been removed, reducing the chances of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quarter fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. The Miami Criteria specify a 50% (half) fall, not a 25% (quarter) fall, and the timeframe is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Option B. Quarter fall in 10 min: This is incorrect. While the 10-minute timeframe is correct, the required decrease is 50% (half), not 25% (quarter).

 

Option C. Half fall in 5 min: This is incorrect. Although the 50% (half) fall is correct, the timeframe specified by the Miami Criteria is 10 minutes, not 5 minutes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Miami Criteria for intraoperative PTH measurement indicate a successful parathyroidectomy if there is a 50% or greater drop in PTH level from the highest preoperative level within 10 minutes after the excision of the hyperfunctioning parathyroid gland.

questions.text: Injury of the lower brachial plexus leads to Klumpke's paralysis. What is the characteristic clinical finding seen in this lesion? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Claw hand

 

The characteristic clinical finding in Klumpke's paralysis is a complete claw hand.

 

 

In Klumpke's paralysis, there's an injury to the lower brachial plexus, particularly affecting the C8 and T1 roots. This leads to weakness or paralysis of the small hand muscles, specifically those innervated by the ulnar nerve. Patients have hyperextension at the MCP joints and flexion at the IP joints of the 4th and 5th fingers, giving the appearance of a "claw hand". The "clawing" is most evident when the patient tries to extend the fingers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Policeman tip hand (also known as "Bishop's hand") : This deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalangeal (IP) joints of the 4th and 5th fingers. It's seen in situations where there's a combined injury to both the median and ulnar nerves. This term, however, is not as commonly used in modern medical literature.

 

Option B. Wrist drop : This is seen with injury to the radial nerve. A patient with wrist drop will have difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers. This can be due to injury or compression of the radial nerve anywhere along its course, but often it's associated with injury in the axillary or upper arm region.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: Injury to the lower brachial plexus, especially the T1 root, can also involve the sympathetic fibers leading to Horner's syndrome, which is characterized by miosis (constricted pupil), ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating) on the affected side. While Horner's syndrome can be associated with a Klumpke's injury, it is not the most characteristic clinical finding for Klumpke's paralysis. The claw hand is more directly related to the primary neural injury of Klumpke's paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klumpke's paralysis, also known as Dejerine-Klumpke palsy, is a type of brachial plexus injury that affects the lower brachial plexus nerves (C8 and T1) that control the muscles of the forearm and hand.

 

Causes:

 

  • Brachial plexus injury involving the C8 and T1 nerve roots.
  • This injury can occur during childbirth if excessive force is applied during delivery or if the infant's shoulder becomes impacted in the birth canal.
  • Trauma, such as a fall or car accident, can also cause a brachial plexus injury and lead to Klumpke's paralysis.
  • Other less common causes include tumors or inflammation in the area.

 

Symptoms

 

  • Weakness or paralysis of the muscles of the hand and forearm,
  • Numbness or tingling in the hand and fingers, and a weakened grip.
  • In severe cases, there may also be a loss of sensation in the affected arm.

 

Treatment may include physical therapy, occupational therapy, and in some cases, surgery.
